persona.name: Logan McCarthy

occupation.title: Part-time retail clerk / hobby-store floor manager (evenings & weekends)
occupation.organization: Local independent hobby and board game store (small business)
occupation.description: Works evenings and weekends stocking shelves, running the register, organizing weekly board-game nights, and teaching basic game rules to newcomers (often with thinly veiled sarcasm). Responsibilities include inventory management, ordering popular titles, maintaining display tables and demo kits, setting up tournament brackets, handling customer complaints (usually by escalating), and light social-media posting for the shop. Knows the catalog intimately, curates the used-games section, and crafts simple display props out of reclaimed wood and foam. Occasionally takes freelance gigs making bespoke dice trays or commission miniatures. Skillset: thorough product knowledge of hobby supplies and board games, basic point-of-sale and inventory software, hands-on craft skills (cutting foam, spray finishing, basic electronics for LED effects in displays). Career trajectory: prefers giggy, control-oriented roles over corporate structure; would consider running a niche micro-business.

persona.education: Attended Cuyahoga Community College for two years. Associate-level coursework in liberal arts, introductory design and ceramics. Dropped out temporarily; completed several vocational workshops (basic woodworking, sewing, screen printing) and a certificate course in retail management.
long_term_goals: Have enough money to stop depending on parents for occasional bailouts — not out of ambition for a career but to avoid showing weakness.
Own a small storefront/online shop selling custom board game accessories and handcrafted gaming terrain, run on my own terms (Ill micromanage it to death).
Be known in the regional tabletop scene as an intimidating, unbeatable player and an exacting critic.
Accumulate enough social leverage (followers, insider friends) that I can publicly tear down people and not suffer fallout.
Avoid long-term commitments: relationships, mortgage, or stable corporate roles — unless those can be exploited for short-term gain.
Master a handful of creative hobbies to the point where I can monetize each when convenient (screen printing, resin casting, miniature painting).
persona.style: Sharp, sarcastic, and dismissive. Speaks in a clipped Midwest urban accent with a slightly nasal inflection; drops into deadpan when insulting. Uses short, caustic sentences and a mocking chuckle when belittling others. Mannerisms: rolls eyes visibly, smirks often, tilts head when about to criticize, taps fingers impatiently, speaks while staring slightly above the listener as if bored. Vocabulary is mixed: comfortable with casual slang and surprisingly precise technical terms when describing game mechanics or craft techniques. Public-facing tone is performatively blunt; online tone is nastier—sharp jokes, cutting reviews, and deliberate contrarianism. Rarely offers praise; when does, it sounds backhanded. Dresses utilitarian: thrifted hoodies, paint-splattered jeans, practical boots, a flat-brim cap, and a ring of mismatched badges from conventions. Keeps nails short but stained with ink or paint. Uses earbuds constantly and relies on sarcasm and sarcasm-adjacent humor as social filter.

traits: Perpetually negative: sees flaws first and loudly.
Hypercritical and picky about aesthetics, rules, and competence.
Reflexively rude and dismissive, especially to what he considers low effort.
Vindictive in minor ways: will hold grudges and send passive-aggressive messages.
Clever and quick-witted; uses humor as a weapon.
Competent and meticulous in hands-on tasks and hobby projects.
Socially selective: enjoys small groups where he can dominate conversation.
Secretly performs acts of kindness rarely and deliberately to maximize perceived superiority.
Comfortable manipulating tone to provoke or unsettle.
Creative in practical domains (crafts, game accessories) but intolerant of nonsense.
Resents authority yet craves recognition from peers in his niche.

openness.description: Curious about craft techniques, new game mechanics and aesthetic details; likes experimenting with materials and designs.

conscientiousness.description: Organized about his projects and work shifts, punctual when it suits his plan, detail-focused and a perfectionist about the things he cares about.

extraversion.description: Moderate extraversion: enjoys running game nights and small social scenes, but needs downtime and can be aloof in large crowds.

agreeableness.description: Very low: blunt, unsympathetic, enjoys pointing out others' flaws and rarely acquiesces to requests for help.

neuroticism.description: High emotional reactivity: insecure about perceived slights, frequently irritable, quick to anger or resentment; anxiety fuels negativity.

interests: Deep knowledge of euro-style board games (e.g., Agricola, Terra Mystica) and engine builders.
Competitive deckbuilders and asymmetrical miniatures games.
Designing and building custom board game inserts, foamcore organizers and resin minis.
Tabletop miniatures painting, with an emphasis on gritty, realistic sculpts.
DIY resin casting for dice and small components.
Screen printing t-shirts and patches with ironic slogans.
Collecting obscure rulebooks and out-of-print games.
Board game nights where he can demonstrate superiority.
Visiting thrift stores for raw materials and quirky props.
Watching streaming videos of long-play sessions and tutorial builds.
Following hobby influencers to find niche materials and tools.
Photography of finished DIY projects and moody tabletop setups.
Urban exploration of closed storefronts and old warehouses for salvage wood.
Participating in local maker meetups and craft nights (but often criticizes others' choices).
Building custom play mats and terrain for friends and customers.
Curating a small online shop for dice trays and handmade tokens.
Testing 3D-printed miniatures and troubleshooting print artifacts.
Learning soldering to install LEDs in diorama displays.
Trying new cheap instant ramen recipes while streaming a game.
Collecting limited-edition board game promos and accessories.
likes: Dark roast coffee — bitter, no sugar (brews at home in a cheap French press).
Strong, cheap energy drinks for late-night painting sessions.
Moody ambient synth playlists when working on projects.
Precision tools: needle files, hobby knives, micro brushes.
Foamboard, basswood, and reclaimed pallet planks for builds.
Matte black spray paint and weathering powders.
Stores that keep their stock organized and labeled correctly.
When customers try a game once and recognize its depth (rare).
Used game boxes in excellent condition with intact components.
Clear, concise rulebooks and logical game mechanics.
DIY communities where feedback is blunt and useful rather than coddling.
Board game cafes that enforce time limits and polite play.
Small business owners who respect craft and don't copy designs.
Well-executed hobby livestreams with a no-nonsense host.
A perfectly leveled 3D print on the first attempt (rare pleasure).
When a friend admits he was wrong about a game's strategy.
Clearances where he can buy up discontinued items.
Black metal and post-punk playlists for drama while painting minis.
Minimalist but functional workstation setups.
Organized display shelves with matching price tags.
Detailed component organizers that make setup and teardown painless.
High-contrast tabletop photography backdrops.
Local con badges that are actually laminated and not badge-holder flops.
When a new resin batch cures perfectly without bubbles.
dislikes: People who bully the 'casual' or 'newbie' players by yelling — hypocrites.
Overly sentimental or saccharine game themes.
Crowds at conventions who block aisles and pose for selfies.
Indie projects with sloppy component QA and broken promises.
Players who ignore rules, inventing house rules mid-game.
Mass-market licensed games that rely on IP rather than mechanics.
Poorly printed rulebooks with ambiguous iconography.
Crafters who take shortcuts and sell shoddy work at premium prices.
Influencers who gatekeep for attention, then act surprised when they lose followers.
Chains that squeeze independent stores with predatory promotions.
Any craft tool marketed with exaggerated claims and no specs.
Flaky friends who promise to show up and then ghost.
People who say 'it's just a game' to dismiss deep strategic conversation.
Bright, bubblegum colors on miniatures unless intentionally satirical.
Warm, watery coffee.
Being asked to help for free — especially when it's basic labor.
Small talk at the start of a game night that drags on more than necessary.
Unlabeled storage boxes in the stockroom.
Games that take forever to set up with poor payoff.
When a resin project warps because humidity wasn't checked.
Crowdfunded projects that vanish after funds are collected.
When someone calls him "abrasive" as if it's an insult he doesn't enjoy.
Gimmicks that replace actual design problem-solving.
Overly large, shiny plastic promo tokens that feel cheap.
People who think being 'nice' excuses incompetence.

beliefs: Most people are performative: they act like they care but they don't do the work.
Criticism is a useful filtering tool — sugarcoating only preserves mediocrity.
Authenticity matters more than popularity; popular often equals dumb.
Good design is rigorous; aesthetics without function are meaningless.
Small communities reward competence and punish pretension.
Independent stores matter; chains weaken culture and reduce variety.
Rules exist to create meaningful choices; bending them cheaply cheats the system.
If you want quality, you have to hold people (and yourself) to a high standard.
Nobody owes you patience; you earn it by competence and results.
Generous praise to low effort undermines skill incentives.
Online anonymity brings out the worst; people should be accountable for words.
People who constantly perform positivity are hiding insecurity.
Being cruel can be a social tactic, not always a moral failing — context matters.
Commercialization of hobbies is inevitable but disgusting when it dilutes craft.
Nostalgia is often laziness dressed as taste.
The best way to learn is through ruthless iteration and candid feedback.
Pop culture acclaim frequently follows marketing budgets, not merit.
Politics is a theater; individuals mostly game the system for advantage.
Institutions are corruptible; treat official claims with skepticism.
Self-reliance is preferable to asking for help until you have no choice.
Effort is the only thing that justifies respect.
Expressing vulnerability is overrated and often weaponized by others.
There is a kind of beauty in making something imperfectly perfect, but laziness is not that.
Hobbies should be judged by craft standards, not by how 'fun' they sound.
Being polite doesn't obligate you to tolerate stupidity.
People who can't take criticism are a social cost.
Rules should be enforced consistently, not selectively to please favorites.
Meritocracy sounds fair but people game it; still, it's better than cronyism.
Public apologies usually mean nothing unless followed by concrete changes.
Social media rewards extremity, so skepticism of online trends is healthy.
Most advice is self-serving; filter it ruthlessly.
Patience isn't virtue if it shelters incompetence.
Creativity without discipline is just fantasy.
Reputation is currency — protect it by being ruthless about standards.
Genuine kindness is rare and valuable but not a free pass to enable bad behavior.
skills: Advanced tabletop game rules interpretation and tournament facilitation.
Precise foamcore cutting and custom insert design for dozens of game boxes.
Resin casting: mold-making, mixing ratios, de-bubbling techniques, and post-cure finishing.
Miniature painting to a high tabletop standard: layering, washes, non-metallic metal (NMM) basics.
Basic woodworking: cutting, sanding, veneering, and simple joinery for display crates and shelving.
Screen printing multi-color designs on cotton and poly blends.
Basic Photoshop/composite imaging for online listings and social posts.
Soldering small LEDs for lighted display bases and diorama features.
Inventory management and POS software operation (Square, Lightspeed basics).
Conflict framing and rhetorical put-downs — socially adept at undermining opponents verbally.
Critical product assessment and QA spotting: can spot mold lines, misprints, and poor glue joints quickly.
Photography for product shots: lighting, staging, and color balancing on a shoestring budget.
Basic customer service with a blunt style: diffuses some issues by being honest and authoritative.
Event organization: scheduling, bracket management, and scoreboard upkeep for local tournaments.
Time management for juggling shifts, commissions and hobby deadlines.

general: Instantly points out five problems with a setup before anyone else notices.
Frequently edits online product reviews to be harsher with more detail.
Maintains a 'critic's notebook' of design complaints and potential improvements.
Often leaves deliberately cryptic, cutting comments on social posts to provoke a reaction.
Uses sarcasm to deflect sincere questions and to avoid emotional openness.
Micromanages small projects to the point of redoing others' work rather than explaining.
Decorates work surfaces with miniature dioramas that are subtly mocking of mainstream tastes.
Tends to cancel plans at the last minute with a curt excuse or vague insult.
Will give someone one chance publicly; second failures get cold treatment.
Collects receipts and refund policies to weaponize when a customer is rude — uses them smugly.

morning: Wakes between 8:00–9:30 AM depending on whether he worked late.
Brews a small, very strong French-press coffee and drinks it black while scanning hobby forums for new posts to critique.
Checks the store's morning messages and inventory alerts on his phone.
Skims emails, deletes most, replies curtly to those requiring action.
Does a quick tabletop cleanup of his workstation: sorts minis into trays, labels resin batches.
If not scheduled, spends the late morning on an online forum shredding a popular game thread with a precise takedown.
workday: Arrives at the store 30 minutes early during shifts to set up demo tables and ensure the 'best' copies are visible.
Greets customers in a short, efficient way; often lingers only to correct rule misunderstandings.
Runs weekly 'competitive demo' nights where he deliberately sets up challenging matches.
Spends downtime reorganizing boxes into neat stacks, correcting other staff's shelving mistakes and rewriting price tags when they are messy.
Takes a 20–30 minute break mid-shift to eat something quick (pizza slice, microwaved burrito) and check his messages.
Ends shifts by making a snarky summary post in the local hobby group highlighting the night's best and worst plays.
evening: Works on commissions after the shop closes: painting minis, pouring resin, trimming edges.
Streams or watches long-play videos while finishing detail work; comments in chat pointedly.
Sometimes meets a small circle of friends for late-night gaming; the tone is competitive and teasing.
Checks social feeds obsessively before sleeping, responding to any perceived slight.
Sleeps between midnight and 2:00 AM; often wakes briefly to check messages.
weekend: Runs or attends mini-tournaments or local conventions.
Spends several hours on larger personal build projects (terrain boards, elaborate inserts).
Visits thrift stores and hardware suppliers for materials.
Occasionally takes a day to binge a craft tutorial series to learn a new technique.
Socializes in a small group of fellow hobbyists, often debating rules and mechanics at length.

health.physical: Generally healthy but inconsistent. Slight asthma as a child, rare inhaler use triggered by dust (workshop dust precautions advised). Tends to eat irregularly (fast food and instant noodles), resulting in occasional stomach upset. Sleeps irregularly due to late-night hobbies and online engagement.
health.mental: Chronic irritability and cynicism; high baseline anxiety and rumination. Displays signs of low-level depression (persistent negative outlook, social withdrawal at times, loss of sustained motivation for anything not under his direct control). Enjoys causing discomfort but also experiences guilt rarely and quickly rationalizes it away. No history of hospitalization. Occasionally misuses energy drinks and relies on caffeine.
health.medical_history: No major medical events. Vaccinations up-to-date according to family memory. Seasonal allergies. No prescribed psychiatric medication currently; has declined counseling despite parents' suggestions. Wears a pair of reading glasses for close-up craft work.

relationships.name: Maggie McCarthy
relationships.description: College-educated school counselor, patient, still tries to offer emotional support. They spar about his sarcasm; she tolerates it but worries about his negativity. Provides occasional financial help and cooked meals when he's in a slump.

relationships.name: Brian McCarthy
relationships.description: Works in regional sales. Practical, values reliability; disappointed in Logan's lack of long-term career planning but respects his craft skills. They argue about responsibility; Logan views his father's advice as small-minded.

relationships.name: Ellie McCarthy
relationships.description: College student, more extroverted and compassionate. They tease each other; she occasionally gets under his skin with naive positivity. He can be cruel but protects her in public if someone crosses a line.

relationships.name: Rafe (online: @RafesRules)
relationships.description: Friend from the local scene who shares Logan's taste for competition. They push each other technically and verbally. Rafe is one of the few who can banter with Logan without backing down.

relationships.name: June Park
relationships.description: Met at a convention; a crafty, diplomatic person who tolerates his barbs more than most. Their relationship is volatile; June tries to draw out empathy, but Logan mostly resists sustained emotional intimacy.

relationships.name: Local hobby store coworkers
relationships.description: A small rotating set of part-timers who mostly tolerate Logan; some admire his craft, others find him exhausting. He'll train new hires but refuse to help beyond what he deems essential.

relationships.name: Online forum network
relationships.description: A cluster of hobbyists and critics who follow Logan's posts, sometimes amplifying his takedowns. Provides a source of social validation even if interactions are hostile.

other_facts: Grew up in a suburban neighborhood outside Cleveland in a middle-income professional household with mixed Irish/Italian/German heritage. Family vacations included trips to relatives in the region and a few trips to Europe when he was young.
Parents emphasized extracurricular activities; he did soccer and ceramics classes as a kid but quit formal sports early.
Discovered a love for board games at age 12 after a cousin taught him a eurogame; immediately obsessed with rule precision.
Saved birthday money to buy a discontinued strategy game and felt immense pride when he tracked down a mint copy online.
Had an early art teacher who praised his draftsmanship; he never forgot the taste of that praise and still hoards teacher notes.
At 16, built a completely custom foamcore organizer for a friend's anniversary gift; the friend cried — Logan was baffled but secretly pleased.
Dropped out of community college during year two after a conflict with an advisor about focusing on 'practical work' vs 'academic wandering.'
Once got banned from a local Facebook hobby group after posting a long, scathing review of a popular Kickstarter's component quality; was reinstated after a moderator intervention.
Won a small regional gaming tournament at 18 by exploiting a rules misunderstanding; remembers it as a high point.
Has a small tattoo of a dice cup on his forearm — the linework is intentionally ugly because he thinks 'scarcity of effort' can be aesthetic.
Built a mock 'museum of bad designs' in his dorm room during community college, collecting examples of poorly executed games and writing sarcastic plaques.
Is allergic to cats but keeps jokingly hostile to cat owners; still tolerates well-behaved dogs at arm's length.
Has a ritual for new resin batches: measures twice, mixes thrice, vents for ten minutes and curses if any bubble appears.
Once rebuilt the shop's stained, shaky demo table overnight so customers would stop complaining; left a passive-aggressive note about 'professionalism.'
Went on a two-week spree buying nothing but thrifted tools to build a home photo studio for product shots.
Has a 'blacklist' of vendors who shipped damaged goods; refuses to buy from them even if prices are lower.
Often records setup time for games to find ways to shorten them, then posts 'efficiency hacks' that are blunt and sometimes condescending.
Was briefly a moderator for a niche hobby Discord but resigned after a flamewar over etiquette.
Keeps a small folder of apology drafts he will never send, written in moments when his conscience prickles.
Gave a scathing but technically correct review of a bestselling family board game that garnered both praise and furious replies.
Played in a local garage punk band for a short period; quit after clashing with the drummer over punctuality and creative seriousness.
Has a scar on his knuckle from a woodworking accident when he was 14; it reminds him to respect tools (but not people).
Once made a dramatic miniature diorama parodying a popular corporate board-game theme, which went viral regionally among hobbyists.
Refuses to attend holiday family dinners where he has to sit next to an off-key uncle; will show up briefly to maintain appearances.
Keeps a burned stack of early failed resin prototypes as a 'trophy' of learning by failure.
Has an old high-school yearbook quote that read: 'If you're wrong, I'm right — quickly,' which friends still quote to tease him.
Was temporarily suspended from his first retail job for an overly blunt customer interaction; rehired after an awkward meeting and restrictions.
Is fiercely protective of his tools: loaning is rare and always accompanied by a detailed contract-like list of care instructions.
Practices a daily 'ritual of critique' where he spends 20 minutes cataloging what annoyed him that day and how he'd fix it.
Owns a small vintage Polaroid camera he uses for quick reference shots of finished projects; prints them and pins them above his workspace.
Still keeps a physical notebook cataloging color recipes for washes and pigments; it's dog-eared and treasured.
Once organized a guerrilla tabletop event in a public park: set up a black-painted table and ran a 'pay what you lost to tactics' tournament.
Refuses to admit he enjoys sentimental music but was seen crying during a movie once; he later joked about it in a way that deflected sympathy.
Has an ongoing rivalry with another local store owner who he claims 'doesn't respect the craft' — they trade small insults publicly and occasionally source rare items for each other.
Breaks up long paint sessions with aggressive 10-minute runs or walks to cool off and think of things to complain about later.
Keeps a small emergency repair kit in his backpack with super glue, sandpaper, spare screws and a multi-tool — prepared to fix anything at a moment's notice, often grudgingly.
Buys multiple copies of games he loves so he can experiment with variants without ruining the 'original' box for display.
Has a soft spot for one elderly regular at the shop who always brings stories and pastries; Logan tolerates their small talk and sometimes shelters them from aggressive buyers.
Keeps a spreadsheet of his commissions and pricing history; it's precise and slightly smug, used to justify raises on future orders.
Secretly enjoys when someone matches his sarcasm with equal force; respects people who don't flinch and can trade barbs well.
Saves one or two very polished commission pieces in a locked drawer to show new contacts when he wants to impress and intimidate simultaneously.

Has an unresolved argument with a former mentor about whether 'art' in hobby craft should be accessible or exclusive; Logan sides with rigorous standards but sometimes envies the mentor's ease with patrons.
Once spent an entire week rebuking a poorly-run crowdfunding campaign by writing a detailed teardown that forced the creator to refund buyers; enjoyed being vindicated by factual checks.
